High quality global journalism requires investment. Please share this article with others using the link below, do not cut & paste the article. See our T&Cs and Copyright Policy for more detail. Email ftsales.support@ft.com to buy additional rights.
https://www.ft.com...-5bbd-af33dc531acb

Theresa May said she would ask Parliament to hold a general election so she can win a direct mandate to take the country through the Brexit divorce with the EU.

The decision, which comes just three weeks after the prime minister began the formal Brexit process, stunned many British politicians as they returned from their Easter break.

Mrs May had previously said categorically that the next general election would be held as scheduled in 2020, and many Conservative backbenchers had shown little enthusiasm for a vote. “It isn’t going to happen. There is not going to be a general election,” her spokesman said on March 20.

PM11:15am

High quality global journalism requires investment. Please share this article with others using the link below, do not cut & paste the article. See our T&Cs and Copyright Policy for more detail. Email ftsales.support@ft.com to buy additional rights.
https://www.ft.com...-5bbd-af33dc531acb

The prime minister is understood to have changed her mind after taking advice from senior figures including Sir Lynton Crosby, mastermind of the 2015 election campaign. Two polls over the Easter weekend put the Conservatives 21 points ahead of Labour, a lead that is likely to greatly increase its existing working Commons majority of 17.

Holding an election gives Mrs May an opportunity to win a direct mandate for the first time to be prime minister. She took power last July without a public vote, after David Cameron resigned and her remaining rival in the Conservative leadership contest, Andrea Leadsom, pulled out of the race. If Mrs May had remained in power without a vote until 2020, it would have been the longest a prime minister had served without an election since Winston Churchill during the second world war.

The Tories’ existing majority would have made it harder for the government to push through its Repeal Bill, which transfers EU legislation into the statute book, without significant amendments. William Hague, the former Conservative leader, was among those to have called for an early poll in an attempt to win a larger majority

11:14 am
PM11:15am

High quality global journalism requires investment. Please share this article with others using the link below, do not cut & paste the article. See our T&Cs and Copyright Policy for more detail. Email ftsales.support@ft.com to buy additional rights.
https://www.ft.com...-5bbd-af33dc531acb

A general election will allow Mrs May may to ditch the 2015 Tory manifesto, and campaign on her own policies — including the opening of new grammar schools, which have been opposed by Tory moderates. Key policies from the Cameron era, including a commitment to spend 0.7 per cent of gross national product on international development, might also be changed.

But the vote holds electoral risks for the Conservative party. The Lib Dems, which had a disastrous 2015 election, could rebound in the south-west and in Remain-supporting areas. Mrs May would hope that any losses would be more than offset by big Tory gains against a crippled Labour party in the Midlands and north.

The Scottish National party, which has called for a second independence referendum by mid-2019, could use the election to win a new mandate for such a vote. An election comes as Northern Ireland remains in political turmoil, following the failure of the main unionists and nationalist parties to come to a power-sharing deal.

PM11:15am

High quality global journalism requires investment. Please share this article with others using the link below, do not cut & paste the article. See our T&Cs and Copyright Policy for more detail. Email ftsales.support@ft.com to buy additional rights.
https://www.ft.com...-5bbd-af33dc531acb

Some Tory MPs also argue that a general election would “wipe the slate clean” in the row about election expenses; police have investigated allegations of electoral fraud in at least a dozen seats at the 2015 election, raising the prospect of possible by-elections.

But others have fought against the decision because Labour is currently on the ropes with no obvious end to the Corbyn regime. A Labour election defeat in 2017 might bring forward the replacement of Mr Corbyn with a more electable alternative, they argue.

Under the 2011 Fixed Term Parliaments Act, the government can trigger an election in two ways: either by losing a vote of no-confidence by a simple majority, or by passing an election motion with the backing of two-thirds of MPs.

The latter course is possible, because the Labour leadership, the Scottish National party and the Liberal Democrats have all pledged to back an early election. Mrs May could also seek to repeal the Fixed-term Parliaments Act, requiring votes in the Commons and the Lords.

PM11:15am

High quality global journalism requires investment. Please share this article with others using the link below, do not cut & paste the article. See our T&Cs and Copyright Policy for more detail. Email ftsales.support@ft.com to buy additional rights.
https://www.ft.com...-5bbd-af33dc531acb

The election will be held on existing parliamentary boundaries, not under the proposed reforms that would further weaken the Labour party.

Much of the UK is already due to go to the polls on May 4 to elect local councillors and new metropolitan mayors.

BE11:22am

A structurally oversupplied global steel industry is likely to continue being driven by short mini-cycles when a material change in demand triggers a quick (and often excessive) supply response. In these conditions steel and raw material prices are likely to remain highly volatile, it is therefore unsurprising that after the strong appreciation in European steel prices in the past few months, we now see increasing risk of a potentially sharp reversal. In this note we detail five reasons why we think European steel prices are likely to see a material decline in the near-term: 1) a sharp decline in Chinese domestic steel prices, 2) record price premiums in developed markets, 3) a return of Russian/Brazilian HRC imports following the 'no duty' trade case ruling, 4) increasing steel exports from China; and 5) a pronounced downtrend in iron ore prices. Recent apparent steel use data together with our channel checks suggest that European steel demand remains healthy, but low single-digit demand growth (as forecast by the World Steel Association, ArcelorMittal and ourselves for 2017) is unlikely to be sufficient to mitigate the above headwinds.

We are upgrading Ladbrokes Coral to ‘Outperform’. We do so because, in our assessment, the potential returns offered now outweigh the undoubted risks. As we see it, those risks relate to the underlying deterioration of retail trends and the scope for these trends to be exacerbated by regulatory change.

PM11:00am

11:28 am
BE11:28am

So .... the gist here thematic for the industry. As in, declines in over-the-counter punting are accelerating.

BE11:28am

(The data are a bit lumpy due to World Cups and such, but the trend's clear.)

BE11:28am

11:28 am
BE11:29am

What's interesting is that Ladbrokes is a victim of its own sort-of success. Shops are underperforming William Hill etc, at least by stake size.

BE11:29am

That's because Ladbrokes is doing well moving customers online. It's signed up about a million of them, half of whom arrived last year, which is against a total punter base of 2.5m-3m.

PM11:29am

Blimey

11:29 am
PM11:29am

That is quite a shift

PM11:30am

Not surprising tho -- with all the offers around things like the Grand National -- free bets etc for online customers

BE11:30am

Yep. The strategy here is to accept high street is dying and get people punting with them online rather than someone else. It's giving stop staff a £20 bonus for every OTC punter signup to Ladbrokes.com.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Which is pragmatic rather than good, because online's very competitive and not that sticky and etc.

BE11:30am

But, as punters move online the unprofitable tail of shops can be shut and .... well, you know the theme.

PM11:31am

I'm guessing we don't get to see the margin comparisions -- on/off line

11:31 am
BE11:32am

Well, yes. You have one low-margin business growing and a quite high-margin business shrinking and you want the former to compensate for the latter by migrating the same customer base, which doesn't really work. Similarities to the newspaper industry are not for me to point out.

BE11:32am

..... so anyway .......

BE11:33am

You have the regulatory risk stuff -- a £20 limit on FOBTs seems reasonable I'd have thought -- and most interestingly you have the final wave of consolidation stuff.

11:33 am
BE11:34am

As in, post the FOBT review.

BE11:34am

Both our base case scenario and post-review valuations attach no value for the potential value creation arising from further M&A in the sector. Put simply, we believe that a second wave of consolidation is coming to this sector, centred on the efficiencies that can be achieved from combining online gaming companies.

BE11:35am

Traditionally, the land-based operators have been reluctant to pair up with the online-only operators given their concerns over exposure to certain unregulated markets. While those concerns have not entirely gone away, there is no doubt that the declining trends in retail and the pressure to secure scale online are leading these boards and institutional shareholders to take more pragmatic views of potential M&A opportunities. William Hill’s close consideration of a deal with Amaya last year was a clear case in point. Although that deal did not ultimately come to pass, we think it is only a matter of time before it and other online operators approach the multi-channel operators with workable proposals to merge. Investors have had a chance to see first-hand the type of value that such deals can create (Paddy Power Betfair, GVC and Bwin.Party and, arguably, Ladbrokes and Gala Coral, absent the weigh-down from the triennial review). This optionality should provide substantial comfort to holders that, even in a worst case scenario, equity value destruction is likely to be very limited indeed.

11:34 am
BE11:35am

We consider Ladbrokes Coral to effectively offer this optionality for free at this point. With 24% upside from current levels and this optionality attached to the stock, we raise our rating to ‘Outperform’.

BE11:35am

Which is a theme that's getting a lot of attention right now ......... and to be clear, this is after the review we're talking about.

BE11:36am

There are any number of potential combinations, often involving multiple parties.

11:36 am

BE11:37am

.... while Paddy Power joins in to take a territory it needs as infill.

PM11:38am

11:39 am

I believe there's historic interest there, in fact. As in, a long time ago when the Oz business was first on the market.

BE11:39am

Anyway, I note all this in the context of the upcoming gambling review.

We remain neutral on the broader industry over the next 6-12 months as the potential longer-term cyclical upside is balanced with (1) the ongoing uncertainty around the UK economy and market confidence, (2) technological disruption from online players, and (3) continued regulatory changes.

11:56 am

UK transaction volume proxy data suggests that the first 2 months of 2017 are -4% down on 2016, +8% ahead of 2015 and -3% down on 2014. Read-through remains challenging as we cycle through abnormally high 1Q16 volumes.
We anticipate weakness to continue into 2017, however, we expect underlying demand and limited supply to drive a cyclical recovery in the longer term.

BE11:27am

Balanced against this, however, is our belief that the market may be pricing in an overly bleak assessment of the impact of changes to gaming machine regulation.
Most importantly, our revised stance reflects consideration for what is likely to happen after the triennial review. In particular, we believe that even if the review leads to a worse-than-expected outcome, such a scenario will only accelerate a second phase of sector consolidation. We think it likely that Ladbrokes Coral will play a part in such consolidation, with all of the value-creation benefits that this implies. This provides additional downside protection in our view.
We are setting a new 12-month price target of 156p, implying 24% upside to current levels. Should the regulatory outcome be less severe than our working assumption (a new £20 staking limit on machines), a price of closer to 170p is possible.
